title: The Nazarite Vow and Priestly Blessing
shortSummary: Numbers chapter 6 details the special Nazarite vow, a voluntary separation unto the Lord involving abstinence from wine, avoidance of dead bodies, and letting hair grow long as a sign of holiness. The chapter concludes with the Lord’s instructions for the priestly blessing, a profound benediction invoking God's protection, grace, and peace upon Israel.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Journey after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who receives God's instructions and communicates them to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest, instructed to bless the children of Israel with the priestly blessing.

keyCharacters.name: The Nazarite
keyCharacters.description: Any man or woman who voluntarily takes the Nazarite vow to separate themselves unto the Lord for a period.

definitions.definition: A person who takes a special vow to be set apart for God, involving abstaining from wine, avoiding contact with the dead, and not cutting their hair.
A solemn promise made voluntarily to God, often involving specific commitments or sacrifices.
A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins and restore fellowship with God.
A sacrifice expressing gratitude and fellowship with God, often shared in a communal meal.
A divinely ordained benediction pronounced by the priests to invoke God's favor and protection upon the people.

outline.heading: Instructions for the Nazarite Vow
outline.description: God commands Moses to instruct Israel about the Nazarite vow, emphasizing separation from wine, grape products, cutting hair, and contact with the dead to maintain holiness during the vow period.

outline.heading: Purification if the Nazarite is Defiled
outline.description: Guidelines are given for the Nazarite who becomes defiled by contact with a dead body, including shaving the head and offering specific sacrifices to restore their vow’s sanctity.

outline.heading: Completion of the Nazarite Vow
outline.description: Upon completing the vow, the Nazarite brings offerings to the tabernacle, shaves their head, and the hair is burned on the altar; thereafter, they may drink wine, signifying the vow’s fulfillment and restoration.

outline.heading: The Priestly Blessing
outline.description: God instructs Moses to tell Aaron and his sons to bless Israel with a threefold blessing invoking God’s protection, grace, and peace, placing His name upon the people as a sign of divine favor.

application: Commit to periods of spiritual separation and dedication to God, seeking holiness through obedience and self-discipline.
Recognize the importance of cleansing and restoration when sin or defilement occurs, turning to God for forgiveness and renewal.
Value the power of God’s blessing and pray regularly for His protection, grace, and peace over yourself and others.
Obey God’s commands faithfully, understanding that vows and promises made to Him are sacred and must be fulfilled.

keyVerses.text: All the days of the vow of his separation there shall no razor come upon his head: until the days be fulfilled, in the which he separateth himself unto the LORD, he shall be holy, and shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the outward sign of the Nazarite’s holy separation and commitment to God.

keyVerses.text: The LORD bless thee, and keep thee: The LORD make his face shine upon thee, and be gracious unto thee: The LORD lift up his countenance upon thee, and give thee peace.
keyVerses.significance: These verses contain the powerful priestly blessing that invokes God’s protection, favor, and peace upon His people.

keyVerses.text: This is the law of the Nazarite who hath vowed, and of his offering unto the LORD for his separation, beside that that his hand shall get: according to the vow which he vowed, so he must do after the law of his separation.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the seriousness of vows made to God and the necessity of faithful obedience to their terms.
